title.text: PLUJAGH at SemEval-2016 Task 11: Simple System for Complex Word Identification

abstractContent.text: This paper presents the description of a system which detects complex words.
It solely uses information regarding the presence of a word in a prepared vocabulary list.
The system outperforms multiple more advanced systems and is ranked fourth for the shared task, with minimal loss to the best system.
F-score optimization guaranteed the first place in this measurement.
Different features are considered and evaluated.
The rule "the simplest methods give the best results" is confirmed.

introductionContent.text: The goal of Complex Word Identification (CWI) is to detect words in a text that are complex (not easy to understand) for some group of people.
CWI is one of the tasks of.
CWI can be treated as the first step of Lexical Simplification (LS).
Complex words were identified using n-grams, the length of the word, and the number of syllables ().
The resources exploited in this task include Wikipedia, WordNet, Google Web 1T corpus.
Additional annotation of input sentences was performed by: a part-of-speech tagger, and word sense disambiguation.
A similar task is the prediction of the readability of a whole text.
In comparison, in CWI, each word has to be scored.
The applied methods are summarized in.
This paper presents findings regarding the necessary data and the performed experiments.
For the final submission, a simple system was chosen, which scored at fourth place.

datasetContent.text: All experiments were conducted by employing cross-validation on raw vote data.
Training data were aggregated -a word is labeled as complex if at least two annotators marked it accordingly.
Tree-based classifiers achieved the best results (except for word embeddings).
presents the G-scores obtained by training a classifier with each of the features.
Combining features gives only a slightly better score.
